Matthew Adam Turner, PhD

Theoretical and computational social scientist

Current role

I am currently a Pandemic Preparedness Postdoctoral Scholar working in James Holland Jones’ Human Evolutionary Ecology and Health group in the Social Sciences Division of the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability at Stanford University.

Pursuing a rigorous understanding of collective adaptation

My work contributes to understanding how populations of individuals collectively adapt to their social and physical environment through exploratory learning, social influence, and evolution. Wise collective adaptation is essential for mitigating risk of disasters caused by climate change, global pandemics, or other threats. I develop mechanistic models of how collective adaptation emerges from ongoing social interactions, and how social networks, environmental variability, and other contextual factors affect the nature and success of collective adaptation. Mechanistic models allow us to computationally test the logic of potential hypotheses about how collective adaptation emerges, or to explain emergent collective adaptation in empirical data. What we learn from this contributes to ongoing efforts to develop a rigorous understanding of collective adaptation. This rigorous understanding can be used to design wiser collective action. My blog collects research notes and tutorials on how I contribute to the collective effort to rigorously understand collective adaptation [link: The RUCA Blog]. Please also see some select works below that outline my contributions to a rigorous understanding of collective adaptation or my CV to learn more.

Select works

Turner, M. A., Singleton, A. L., et al. (2023). Minority-group incubators and majority-group reservoirs support the diffusion of climate change adaptations. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences. [link]

Turner, M. A., Moya, C., Smaldino, P. E., & Jones, J. H. (2023). The form of uncertainty affects selection for social learning. Evolutionary Human Sciences, 5. [link]

Turner, M. A., & Smaldino, P. E. (2022). Mechanistic Modeling for the Masses - commentary on Yarkoni, “The generalizability crisis.” Behavioral and Brain Sciences, 45(E33). [link]

Turner, M. A., & Smaldino, P. E. (2020). Stubborn extremism as a potential pathway to group polarization. Proceedings of the 42nd Annual Conference of the Cognitive Science Society. [link]

Turner, M. A., & Smaldino, P. E. (2018). Paths to Polarization: How Extreme Views, Miscommunication, and Random Chance Drive Opinion Dynamics. Complexity. [link]

Previous experience

Before I received my PhD in Cognitive and Information Sciences from the University of California, Merced, I received an MS in Applied Physics from Rice University and worked professionally as a data engineer and lead research software developer in Moscow, Idaho.
